The  Project  is  located  in  the  northwestern  part  of  Yunnan  province, 
which is relatively poor. The Project is designed to  promote sustainable 
economic  growth  by  constructing  167  kilometers  (km)  of  railway  line 
from  Dali  to  Lijiang.  The  Project  will  develop  an  efficient,  safe,  and 
environmentally sustainable railway transport system in the region. The 
Project will facilitate the creation of additional employment and income-
generating opportunities, thus benefiting the poor, and ethnic minorities, 
living in the Project area.  
 
The Project meets the railway sector operational strategy of ADB for the 
PRC to reduce railway  network  constraints  and  to  promote  sustainable 
economic  growth  in  poor  areas  not  served  by  railways.  The  Project  is 
also  in  line  with  the  Government’s  western  development  strategy  to 
provide  less-developed  regions  with  better  infrastructure  to  facilitate 
economic  growth,  thereby  increasing  the  opportunity  for  people  to 
improve their living standards.  
 
The  poor  interior  regions  in  the  PRC  have  not  benefited  as  much  from 
economic  growth  and  reforms  as  the  east  coast.  The  gap  in  economic 
and  social  development  has  increased.  Transport  constraints  and  high 
logistics  costs  are  two  of  the  factors  contributing  to  regional  economic 
disparities and are two of the constraints that prevent the western region 
from capitalizing on its comparative advantages. 
 
The  Project  will  reduce  transport  constraints  in  northwestern  Yunnan 
province  and  provide  connectivity  to  Kunming,  Shanghai,  and  Beijing 
through  three  of  the  16  east-west  and  north-south  national  railway 
corridors.  This  will  provide  accessibility  to  the  ports  of  Fangcheng  and 
Beihai in the PRC and Haiphong in Viet Nam. The Project will promote 
regional cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), of which 
the PRC is an active participant through Yunnan province, which shares 
borders with other GMS countries. 
 
The  Project,  a  joint-venture  railway  between  the  Ministry  of  Railways 
(MOR)  and  Yunnan  provincial  government  (YPG),  will  have  substantial 
managerial  and  financial  autonomy.  The  Project  will  contribute  to

Project Benefits 
and Beneficiaries 

 

The  Project  will  (i) provide  the  shortest  land  route  between  Dali  and 
Lijiang,  key  centers  in  Yunnan  province,  enabling  railway  freight 
operators  and  passengers  to  benefit  from  lower  transport  costs  and 
shorter  travel  distances  and  times;  (ii) increase the corridor’s capacity, 
benefiting consumers and producers of goods and services through the 
provision  of  timely  and  efficient  transport  services  and  lower  logistics 
costs;  (iii) generate  direct  and  indirect  employment  in  the  project-
influenced area, and create jobs and income-earning opportunities (the 
construction  and  operation  of  the  railway  will  employ  much  local 
unskilled labor); (iv) provide an area that lacked adequate cost-efficient 
transportation services with access to broader markets; and (v) stimulate 
local  development  through  tourism,  railway  station  area  development, 
and other infrastructure elements to maximize the railway’s benefits.  
 
The  increased  tax  revenues  generated  by  the  economic  development 
induced by the Project will help finance improved social service facilities 
and basic infrastructure. 
 
The major project beneficiaries will be  (i) freight  users  who  will  switch 
from the existing Class II road and  benefit  from more affordable, faster, 
and  safer  trips;  (ii) passengers, including  tourists,  who  will benefit from 
affordable,  faster,  and  safer  trips;  (iii) the  local  population  who  will 
benefit from the lower prices of commodities and services transported by 
the project railway; (iv) local labor involved  in construction work and  the 
supply  of  materials  during  implementation  and  in  loading/unloading 
during the operation of the railway; (v) local farmers who will be able to 
sell  their  products  at  market  prices  without  paying  a  high  margin  to a 
transport  intermediary;  (vi) local  manufacturers  and  traders  who  can 
increase  production  capacity  or  establish  businesses  and  will transport 
their goods and services by the railway; and (vii) local governments who 
will  benefit  from  the  increased  opportunity  for  local  area  development 
and increased revenues. 
 
The Project will benefit about 1.1 million people living in the project area, 
which includes Dali county, Heqing county, and Lijiang city. Seventy-five 
percent of the beneficiaries live in rural areas, and 30% are poor with an 
annual  net  income  per  capita  of  less  than  CNY900.  The  poverty  and 
social  assessment  looked  at  the  seven  counties  of  the  BOA,  namely 
Eryuan  and  Jianchuan  counties  in  Dali  Bai  prefecture,  Ninglang  and 
Yongsheng  Counties  in  Lijiang  prefecture,  Weixi  and  Xianggelila 
(Zhongdian)  counties  in  Diqing  prefecture,  and  Lanping  county  in 
Nujiang  prefecture.  About  91%  of  the  population  living  in  the  BOA  is 
rural  and  the  poverty  incidence  is  more  than  60%.  The  links  between 
poverty, minorities, difficult topography, and poor transport systems are 
apparent  in  the  project  area  for  the  proposed  Dali-Lijiang  railway. 
Poverty is often caused by geographic remoteness and isolation, limited 
transport  access,  high  transport  costs,  and  poor  access  to  market 
information  as  well  as  limited  access  to  health,  education,  and  other 
social services. 

  

vii 

 
 
The  Project  will  facilitate  the  creation  of  additional  employment  and 
income-generating opportunities. About 96,800 person-years of work will 
be  created  during  construction.  This  will  provide  direct  employment 
opportunities to over 7,000 poor people, the majority of whom are ethnic 
minorities. Railway  station  area  development  will  increase  incomes  in 
local  communities  and  help  generate  local  revenues.  The  Project  will 
facilitate  the  development  of  local  industry  and  tourism,  which  will  help 
generate  additional  opportunities  in  the  future  for  local  people,  who  as 
ethnic  minorities,  prefer  to  remain  in  their  native  lands.  Consultations 
with  the  ethnic  minorities  (such  as  the  Naxi,  Bai,  Tibetans,  Yi,  and 
Mosuo)  in  the  project  area  and  the  BOA  indicated  their  strong  support 
for the Project. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  and  economically  sustainable.  The  6.7% 
financial internal rate of return exceeds the 4.5% weighted average cost 
of capital. The economic internal rate of return is estimated at 17%.  
 
The  railway  will  be  constructed  in  mountainous  terrain,  which  is  a 
significant  technical  challenge.  The  associated  physical  risks  include 
delays,  cost  overruns,  worker  health  and  safety,  and  environmental 
impacts.  These  potential  risks  have  been  assessed  and  appropriate 
mitigating measures provided. 
 
Resettlement will affect about 8,000 people. The railway alignment was 
selected  to  minimize  resettlement,  where  possible.  The  resettlement 
plan includes preferential treatment for employment during construction, 
supply  of  local  materials,  allocation  of  commercial  space  near  railway 
stations, and job training.  
 
Some  of  the  economic  development  induced  by  the  new  railway  line 
may  have  indirect,  adverse  impacts  for  some  ethnic  minorities.  To 
reduce  this  potential  risk,  special  measures  have  been  included  in  the 
resettlement plan and the ethnic minorities development plan  to mitigate 
the effects of social risks such as impoverishment and social exclusion, 
and  to  ensure  compliance  with  ADB's  social  safeguard  policies.  A 
comprehensive  monitoring  system  has  been  included  in  the  Project  to 
monitor  the  impacts  of  development  activities  and  to  take  appropriate 
measures to reduce their impact. 
 
Intermodal  competition  among  railways  and  roads  will  create  market 
risks  to  the  project  railway.  However,  the  existing  road  is  already 
congested and the capacity constraint is expected to worsen. Surveys of 
freight  operators  and  passengers  found  that  the  railway  would  have 
several  advantages  over  other  transport  modes:  lower  fares,  shorter 
travel  times,  safety,  and  punctuality.  The 
increasing  commercial 
orientation of the joint-venture railway will help to lessen the risks posed 
by intermodal competition.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis  

2. 
From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, through to 2003, 
the  PRC  has  experienced  sustained  rapid  economic  growth,  which  has  resulted  in  an 
accordingly  rapid  increase  in  demand  for  transportation.  The  annual  growth  of  passenger 
transport was 9.2% and freight transport grew at 7.1% during the 1978–2003 period. In 2003, 
road  traffic  accounted  for  55.8%  of  total  passenger-kilometers (km) followed by railways with 
34.7%, civil aviation with 9.1%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.5%. The modal split for 
freight ton-kilometers (ton-km) was 53.3% for coastal and inland waterways, 32% for railways, 
13.2% for roads, 1.4% for pipelines, and 0.1% for civil aviation.  
 
Railways are one of the primary mode of transport for long distance and bulk transport. 
3. 
At  the  end  of  2003,  the  PRC’s  railway  system  comprised  a  total  of  73,000  route-km, of which 
60,446 km  are  national,  and  12,554 km  are  joint-venture  and  local  railways.  The  national 
railways  are  state  owned  and  operated  as  an  integrated  system  by  the  Ministry  of  Railways 
(MOR).  The  joint-venture  and  local  railways  consist  of  regional  lines  within  provincial 
boundaries, and are constructed under the sponsorship of provincial governments and/or MOR 
to  serve  local  needs  and  provide  interconnection  to  the  national  railway  network.  Despite  its 
large size, the railway network does not provide adequate coverage for the country’s population 
and land area.1  
 
4. 
PRC railways have the highest freight transport density in the world and  second-highest 
passenger  transport  density  after  Japan.  Locomotive  turnover  is  the  highest  in  the  world. 
Between  1978  and  2003,  railway  freight  grew  from  535 billion  ton-km  to  1,725 billion  ton-km, 
equivalent  to  an  annual  growth  rate  of  4.8%,  while  passenger  traffic  grew  at  6.1%  annually, 
increasing from 109 billion passenger-km to 479 billion passenger-km. The average distance for 
railway journeys increased from 134 km in 1978 to 492 km in 2003, compared with the average 
journey  per  passenger  on  roads,  which  grew  from  35 km  to  53 km  over  the  same  period. 
Despite  such  growth  rates,  the  railways’  capacity  has  lagged  behind  demand,  resulting,  for 
example, in delays in delivering coal to power plants, which in turn, have contributed to power 
shortages.  Given  the  railways’  important  role  in  providing  economic  transportation,  these 
capacity limitations, if not removed, will continue to adversely affect efficient economic growth. 
Because  of  these  concerns,  the  Government  has  adopted  an  aggressive  plan  to  improve  the 
railways  and  has  planned  network  extensions  and  construction  in  underserved  areas.  The 
proposed  Project  will  support  this  plan.  A  project  framework  that  outlines  the  goal,  purpose, 
outputs,  and  activities/inputs  is  in  Appendix 1  and  a  problem  and  constraint  analysis  is  in 
Appendix 2.

Rationale 

19. 
The  project  rationale  reflects  both  network  development  and  sustainable  economic 
growth.  The  largely  mountainous  project  area  is  not  integrated  into  the  economic  mainstream 
partly because of inadequate transportation. The existing Class II road passes through difficult 
terrain, has limited passing capacity, and is occasionally affected by rain. In spite of abundant 
natural resources, many of the people living in this area are poor. Most people living in the area 
work  in  agriculture,  which  is  characterized  by  a  low  level  of  profitability.  People  living  in 
mountainous  areas  supplement  their  incomes  by  engaging  in  animal  husbandry  or  becoming 
migrant  laborers.  The  economic  growth  necessary  to  ameliorate  rural  poverty  has  failed  to 
develop,  partly  because  of  inadequate  transport  services  and  high  transport  costs.  Local 
governments  and  people  living  in  the  project  area  see  the  railway  as  a  key  investment  for 
addressing the problems of lagging economic development and poverty.  
 
20. 
The  railway  link  provides  connectivity  from  northwestern  Yunnan  province  to  Kunming, 
Shanghai, and Beijing via three of the 16 east-west and north-south national rail corridors. This 
will  provide  accessibility  to  the  ports  of  Fangcheng  and  Beihai.  The  Project  will  also  help  in 
promoting the regional cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), of which the PRC 
is  an  active  participant  through  Yunnan  province,  which  shares  borders  with  other  GMS 
countries. Through the rail network, the project area will be linked to the port of Haiphong in Viet 
Nam and the Pan-Asian railway.

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Traffic Forecast 

54. 
The  traffic  forecast  was  made  by  considering  expected  economic  growth,  population 
increase, tourism development potential, local government development plans, market surveys, 
and the assessment of TA consultants and the ADB mission. The freight volume on the DLR is 
forecast to increase from about 640 million ton-km in 2010 to 1,457 million ton-km in 2025. The 
annual growth rate will range between 4.5% and 6.4%. Passenger traffic was forecast based on 
similar  factors, including an assessment of  tourism  development  potential.17 It  was forecast to 
grow  from  448 million  passenger-km  in  2010  to  1,234 million  passenger-km  in  2025  with 
average growth rate ranging between 6.5% and 7.3%. These estimates take into consideration 
the lessons learned from previous railway projects and are consistent with the growth achieved 
on the Guangda railway.  The projected volumes can be accommodated on the  DLR and justify 
construction of the Project. Details are given in Appendix 13. 
 
B. 

Economic Benefits 

55. 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing the with- and 
without-project situations. DLR will reduce the cost of transport to and from the poor, landlocked 
part of northwestern Yunnan  province.  The economic costs of the  Project reflect the costs for 
construction, operation and maintenance, and the value of agricultural production from land lost 
permanently. The economic benefits include  (i) operating cost savings in freight and passenger 
traffic,  (ii) time  saving  in  diverted  passenger  traffic  from  buses,  (iii) the  net  economic  value

benefits.  The  EIRR  for  the  Project  is  17%,  indicating  that  the  Project  is  economically  viable 
(Appendix 13). Results of sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project's economic 
viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 20% reduction in  benefits, do not significantly 
impact economic viability. The capital cost would have to increase by 54% over the estimate for 
the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. The benefit level would have to decrease by 29% 
to achieve the same effect. In light of previous experience in the PRC  railway sector, variations 
of  such  magnitude  are  unlikely.  Project  risks  were  quantified  using  the  “Monte  Carlo”  method, 
i.e.,  considering  the  possible  value  for  key  variables  and  the  probability with which they may 
occur.  The  result  shows  that  the  EIRR  would  exceed  12%  with  95%  probability.  Distribution 
analysis  of  the  Project  was  undertaken  by  determining  the  project  effects  for  various 
beneficiaries,  which  shows  that  a  large  portion  of  the  net  benefits  will  accrue  to  the  local 
economy.

RAILWAY SECTOR ANALYSIS  

Railway Sector Profile  

 
A. 
 
Key  Features.  Despite  the  Government's  efforts  to  increase  the  country's  transport 
1. 
capacity,  serious  constraints  and  bottlenecks  remain,  especially  in  the  road  and  railway 
subsectors.  By  the  end  of  2002,  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  transport  system 
comprised about 72,000 kilometers (km) of railways, 1.69 million km of highways, 121,500 km of 
inland  waterways,  and  1.55 million km  of  civil  aviation  routes.  However,  the  density  of  the 
transport network ranks among the lowest in the world relative to either population or geographic 
area.  From  1978,  when  economic  reforms  were  first  introduced,  through  to  2003,  the  PRC 
experienced sustained rapid economic growth. This resulted in an accordingly rapid increase in 
demand  for  transportation.  The  annual  growth  of  passenger  transport  was  9.2%  and  freight 
transport grew at 7.1% during the 1978–2003 period. In 2003, road traffic accounted for 55.79% 
of total passenger-km, followed by railways with 34.7%, civil aviation with 9.1%, and coastal and 
inland waterways with 0.5%. The modal split for freight ton-km was 53.3% for coastal and inland 
waterways, 32% for railways, 13.2% for roads, 1.4% for pipelines, and 0.1% for civil aviation.  
 
2. 
Recent  Developments. To improve transport inefficiencies and eliminate the transport 
bottlenecks  that  constrain  efficient  economic  development,  the  Government  increased 
investment  in  transport  infrastructure  in  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan  (1996–2000).  Investment in 
transport infrastructure as a share of gross domestic product (GDP) more than doubled in the last 
decade. A World Bank study1 indicates that total transport investment should be increased to at 
least 3.8% of GDP to avoid the economic costs associated with transport constraints. To meet the 
increase in transport demand, more infrastructure investments are needed. The Government has 
continued to accord high priority to transport in the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005). Substantial 
investments  in  the  road  and  railway  subsectors  from  both  domestic  and  international  financing 
sources, including the private sector, are envisaged. 
 
3. 
Future  Development  Priorities  and  Outlook.  The  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005) 
identifies  transportation,  including  railway  development,  as  a  priority.  The  Plan  envisages 
(i) constructing  6,000 km  of  new  lines  to  provide  access  to  unserved  areas  with  the  network 
length  reaching  a  total  of  75,000  route-km,  (ii) providing  3,000 km  of  double  lines  and 
electrifying  5,000 km of key lines to increase capacity, and (iii) increasing operating speeds on 
5,000 km  with  the  total  length  of  such  lines  reaching  15,000 km.  A  total  investment  of 
CNY350 billion,  including  CNY270 billion  on  capital  construction  and  CNY80 billion  for  rolling 
stock,  is  planned  for  the  railway  sector.  During  2003–2007,  the  investments  for  capital 
construction are expected to reach CNY450 billion.  
 
4. 
In 2004, the State Council approved the new railway development plan (up to 2020). The 
plan  seeks  to  expand  the  railway  network  from  72,000 km  to  85,000 km  by  2010,  and  to 
100,000 km by 2020. Increasing train speed is a major goal. Train speed will be raised to over 
200 km  per  hour  on  the  trunk  network  by  2020.  Priority  will  be  given  to  the  development  of 
railways in unserved areas and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. 
The route network length will reach 16,000 km in the western region of the PRC by 2020. The 
plan also calls for separating passenger and freight traffic in heavily trafficked corridors.

ADB’s  Assistance  in  the  Sector.  In  the  railway  subsector,  ADB  has  focused  on

recovery, and improve the management of railways.  
 
7. 
Evaluation of ADB Assistance. Experience from completed and ongoing ADB-financed 
railway projects in the PRC shows strong commitment and generally satisfactory capabilities of 
the  executing  agencies  (EAs)  for  project  implementation.  The  speed  of  implementation  has 
often exceeded the expectations at the time of appraisal. The EAs generally complied with the 
loan  covenants.  Resettlement  and  environmental  management  were  carried  out  satisfactorily. 
Audited  financial  statements  were  submitted  in  a  timely  manner,  and  the  audited  financial 
statements were found generally acceptable. Of ADB’s 11 railway projects, 5 are complete, 3 
are  under  trial  operation,  and  6  are  under  implementation.  The  key  lessons  from  the previous 
railway  projects  highlight  the  need  to  (i) ensure that the EA established for project processing 
and  implementation  is  also  responsible  for  the  project’s  operation;  (ii) prepare  realistic  traffic 
forecasts; (iii) review constraints to traffic on a network basis, and the impact on project viability 
of the existing and/or planned railway lines and other transportation modes that may compete 
with  the  project  facilities;  and  (iv) finance  railway  projects  with  appropriately  determined  debt-
equity  ratios.  The  railway  projects  have  contributed  to  a  dramatic  transformation  of  local 
economies.  The  per  capita  rural  incomes  in  the  project  areas  increased  substantially  from  the 
levels  before  the  project.  Living  standards  were  raised  and  poverty  was  reduced. The project 
performance audit report2 for the ADB-financed Jing-Jiu railway project in the PRC concluded that 
the project was successful and exceeded its original passenger traffic forecasts.

local  governments  to  shift  from  traditional  financing  modes  toward  the  capital  markets.  In  the 
railway sector, a wider role for the private sector is envisaged. MOR has taken steps to create

TRAFFIC FORECAST AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Traffic Forecast 

 
A. 
 
1.  The  Dali–Lijiang  Railway  (DLR)  will  connect  the  poor,  landlocked  part  of  northwestern 
Yunnan  province  with  the  rest  of  the  PRC  through  the  existing  Guangtong–Dali  (Guangda) 
railway,  including  Kunming,  Fangcheng  and  Beihai  ports,  and  Haiphong  in  Viet  Nam.  The 
project  area  has  industrial,  natural  resources,  and  tourism  development  potential.  The  Project 
will also help promote regional cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion. 
 
2. 
Freight  traffic  was  forecast  by  commodity  (i.e.,  coal,  petroleum  products,  steel  and 
nonferrous  metal,  metallic  ore,  nonmetallic  ore,  building  material,  cement,  timber,  chemicals, 
foodstuffs,  and  others)  in  two  categories  differentiated  by  their  economic  impact:  (i) traffic 
diverted from other modes, mainly roads, based on an assessment of the relative service and 
cost competitiveness of the DLR; and (ii) generated traffic that would only move because of the 
DLR.  The  traffic  forecast  was  based  on  the  model  of  the  Second  Survey  and  Design  Institute 
(SSDI), that considered expected economic growth, population increase, tourism development 
potential, local government development plans, market surveys, and the judgment of technical 
assistance (TA) consultants and the ADB mission. Based on the work of the TA consultants and 
the  SSDI,  the  freight  volume  on  the  DLR  is  forecast  to  increase  from  about  640 million  ton-
kilometers (km) in 2010 to 1,457 million ton-km in 2025 with annual growth rates ranging from 
4.5% to 6.4%. Passenger traffic was forecast based on similar factors, with a particular focus on 
tourism  development  potential. 1  Passenger  traffic  is  forecast  to  grow  from  448 million 
passenger-km in 2010 to 1,234 million passenger-km in 2025, with average annual growth rate 
ranging from 6.5% to 7.3% (Table A13.1). 
 
3. 
Transportation  improvements  will  facilitate  the  development  of  natural  resources  and 
associated industries. Local governments are seeking private sector companies to invest in their 
areas, particularly in the tourism industry. Freight and passenger traffic forecasts are considered 
reasonable given that (i) the  Guangda railway, an adjoining line to the DLR, has experienced a 
strong growth  (about  35%  per  annum)  in  the  last  4  years;  (ii) similar  joint-venture  railways in 
PRC have experienced high annual traffic growth (e.g., 26% for freight and 16% for passengers) 
and (iii) potential cross-border traffic would grow between Yunnan  province and Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries under the ASEAN Free Trade Agreement.

Major Assumptions for the Financial Projections 

2. 
The  existing  average  tariff  rates  of  the  Guangda  line  are  used  for  projecting  the 
revenues of both the Guangda and DLR lines. The tariffs, CNY0.25 per ton-km for freight and 
CNY0.27  per  passenger-km1 in 2004, were increased every 5 years by 5% in nominal terms. 
DLR traffic growth rates follow the traffic analysis in Appendix 13. Freight traffic of the Guangda 
line  is  based  on  the  projected  freight  volume  of  8.1 million  tons  in  2010,  11.9 million tons in

the  operations  of  7  pairs  per  day  in  2010,  10  pairs  per  day  in  2015,  and  21  pairs  per  day  in 
2025. This implies a traffic growth rate of 12% during the initial stage of operations and the rate 
will gradually decline to 7% toward the end of the projection period. A business tax of 3.24% is 
imposed on gross revenue. The income tax is 33% on profit before tax.2

average economic asset life. Salaries and wages account for the major portion of general and

300 staff for the operations of the DLR. Financial expenses reflect the expected interest rates 
and outstanding borrowings.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS  

    Appendix 14  51 

 
1. 
The financial evaluation of the Project covers the construction period during 2005–2008 
and  20  years  of  operations  during  2009–2028.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  is 
calculated in constant 2004 prices, after removing the potential impacts of inflation and foreign 
currency fluctuation and on an after-tax basis. Table A14.2 presents the FIRR calculation. The 
key assumptions used in the evaluation are as follows: 
 

(i)  Capital  costs  consist  of  project  costs  excluding  costs  for  local  roads,  price 
contingencies,  and  financial  charges  during  construction.  The  residual  value  is 
estimated based on an average economic life of assets of 25 years. 

 
(ii)  Revenues  of  the  Project  include  (a) freight  and  passenger  revenues  of  the  DLR; 
(b) incremental  revenues  to  the  Guangda  line  as  a  result  of  additional  traffic 
originated  from  or  destined  for  the  connecting  DLR;  and  (c) other  revenues 
including  loading  and  unloading,  warehouse  storage,  parcel  transfer,  and  rental 
income  from  commercial  areas  in  the  train  stations.  Freight  and  passenger 
revenues  are  projected  based  on  forecast  freight  and  passenger  traffic  and  tariffs. 
Freight and passenger tariffs are CNY0.25 per ton-km and CNY0.27 per passenger-
km, respectively. Other revenues are estimated at 12% of total revenues. GDRC will 
be subject to business tax of 3.24% that is to be deducted from gross revenues and 
income tax of 33% on profits before tax. 

 
(iii)  Operating costs include all incremental costs incurred by the operations but exclude 
depreciation  provisions.  Based  on  the  operational  experience  of  GDRC,  the 
operating costs were estimated as follows: fixed cost (including provision for major 
repair and maintenance) CNY447,000 per line-km, freight variable cost of CNY0.07 
per ton-km, and passenger variable cost of CNY0.03 per passenger-km. 

 
2. 
The  estimated  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC),  after  tax,  in  real  terms  was 
calculated based on the capital mix and costs of funds. Costs have been considered as follows: 
(i) the applicable 10-year fixed swap rate plus a provision of ADB’s spread of 0.6% is used for 
ADB debt, (ii) the applicable 10-year fixed swap rate is used for AFD debt, and (iii) the cost of 
equity was assumed to be 8%. The cost of debt is also adjusted to reflect the impact of income 
tax  of  33%.  The  nominal  cost  of  debt  is  converted  to  the  real  cost  of  debt  by  applying  the 
domestic  and  international  inflation  rate  for  domestic  and  foreign  currency  denominated  debt, 
respectively.  
 
3. 
The Project FIRR is estimated to be 6.7%, which is higher than the WACC of 4.5% The 
financial  viability  of  the  Project  is  thus  considered  satisfactory.  The  FIRR  was  subjected  to 
sensitivity analysis  under  various  adverse  conditions.  The  sensitivity  analysis  showed  that  the 
FIRR  would  decrease  to  (i) 5.6%  if  the  revenues  were  to  decrease  by  10%;  (ii) 5.7%  if  the 
Project was to experience a capital cost overrun of 10%; (iii) 6.4% if the operating costs were to 
increase  by  10%;  (iv) 6.0%  if  the  Project  was  to  experience  a  commissioning  delay  of  1  year; 
(v) 4.6% if scenarios (i)–(iii) happen; and (vi) 4.0% if scenarios (i)–(iv) all happen. The Project is 
thus  considered  financially  viable  under  almost  all  adverse  scenarios.  The  results  of  the 
sensitivity analysis are shown in Table A14.3.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN  

 
1. 
The  project  railway  alignment  will  cross  56  villages  in  13  townships  from  Dali  city  to 
Lijiang  city  in  Yunnan  province.  An  estimated  5,913 mu  (394  hectares  [ha])  of  land  will  be 
permanently  acquired,  of  which  about  70.3%  is  currently  under  cultivation.  The  number  of 
affected people will be about 4,159, assuming total loss of cultivated land based on average per 
capita landholdings. The Project will also temporarily require an estimated 1,600 mu (106.7 ha), 
affecting 250 people. About  179,804 square meters (m2) of mainly residential structures will be 
affected,  requiring  relocation  of  680  households  (3,150  people).  The  relocation  of  one school 
and  a  brick-kiln will  require  594 m2 and  affect  an additional  150  people.  The  total  number  of 
people  directly affected is estimated at 7,709. Land acquisition and resettlement impacts were 
minimized  by  aligning  the  railway  away  from  densely  populated  areas,  and  avoiding  irrigated 
land and facilities, where possible, based on consultations with communities. 
 
2. 
The Ministry of Railways (MOR), Western Yunnan Railway Company (WYRC), and local 
governments  prepared  the  resettlement  plan,  with  the  assistance  of  project  preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) consultants and Southwest Jiaotong University (SWJU). It is based 
on the first stage of a preliminary design study, 20 village surveys, 218 household surveys, local 
government  statistics,  and  consultations  with  local  officials,  village  leaders,  and  affected 
households. The resettlement plan will be revised based on the detailed measurement survey, 
including associated cost changes. The revised resettlement plan will be disclosed to affected 
people, and submitted to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for concurrence prior to the start 
of civil works. 
 
The  resettlement  objective  is  to  ensure  that  compensation  and  entitlement  provided  to 
3. 
affected people are adequate to at least maintain their “without-project” standard of living, with 
prospects  of  improvement,  in  line  with  the  Land  Administration  Law  (1998)  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) and with ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement (1995), and policy 
on  indigenous  peoples  (1998).  People  losing  land,  housing,  other  assets,  or  other  means  of 
production will be compensated at replacement cost and assisted in restoring their incomes and 
living  standards.  In  2004,  the  PRC  Constitution  was  amended  to  ensure  that  people  are 
compensated according to law for land expropriated for public projects. 
 
4. 
The  resettlement  plan  stipulates  eligibility/entitlement  provisions  for  affected  people. 
Permanent  land  losses  will  be  compensated  either  through  land  reallocation  within  villager 
groups  or  through  cash  payments  at  rates  of  8–10  times  the  average  annual  output  value 
(AAOV) of the land. A resettlement subsidy is calculated at  4–6 times AAOV. Compensation for 
temporary land loss will be paid directly to the affected people and the land will be restored to 
farmland after use. Compensation for housing losses will be paid directly to the affected people 
at replacement cost, free of demolition expenses and salvaged materials; these households will 
rebuild their own houses within the same village. Crop and tree losses will be directly paid to the 
affected people. Private shops will be paid compensation for relocation and reconstruction. 
 
5. 
Out of 56 affected  villages, five are  seriously  affected.  However,  none of the  farming 
households will incur complete land loss. Also, income loss is thus less severe because planted 
crops typically account for less than 30% of the household’s gross income. Special assistanc e is 
provided to vulnerable households that include orphans, widows, the seriously disabled, and the 
mentally ill.  Ethnic minorities  account  for  83% of the  affected  people,  including  Bai,  Lisu,  and 
Naxi villages. Special measures have been included in the  resettlement plan and the EMDP  to 
ensure  compliance  with  ADB's  social  safeguard  policies  and  guidelines  and  to  enhance 
opportunities for affected people to directly benefit from the Project.

additional  employment  opportunities  in  local  communities,  providing  an  additional  source  of  income  for  people, 
including  poor  households  along  the  alignment  and  in  the  wider  project  area.  Incoming  passengers  and  tourists 
generate additional demand for locally produced goods and services. Secondary development associated with railway 
construction  includes  construction  of  access  roads  and  the  upgrading  and  extension  of  connector  roads  from  the 
station  to  the  main  road  network.  These  roads  help  extend  project  benefits  and  opportunities  to  the  rural  poor 
communities  by  improving  local  infrastructure,  reducing  transport  costs,  increasing  access  to  markets,  stimulating 
price competition, and improving conditions for economic growth, including tourism.

The links between poverty, minority nationality, topography, and transport systems are apparent in the project area for 
the Dali–Lijiang Railway.  The Project will benefit about 1.1 million people in the project area.  The proposed railway 
transverses across 13 townships, directly affecting Dali county-level city and Heqing county in Dali Bai Autonomous 
Prefecture, and Lijiang county. Out of 1.1 million beneficiaries, about  75% are rural with an average rural net income 
per capita of CNY2,202 in 2002, and about 30% are poor with an average net income per capita of less than CNY900. 
A total of 372 key poverty reduction villages are located in the project area, out of which 27 villages are located in the 
project railway corridor townships. About 73% of the people in the project area are ethnic minorities (e.g., Bai, Naxi, 
and Yi). The boundaries of analysis (BOA) includes neighboring counties that could be affected from induced impacts 
from the proposed Project, based on the existing and planned transportation networks. The BOA includes: Eryuan and 
Jianchuan  counties  in  Dali  Bai  prefecture,  Ninglang  and  Yongsheng  counties  in  Lijiang  prefecture,  Weixi  and 
Xianggelila  (Zhongdian)  counties  in  Diqing  prefecture  and  Lanping  county  in  Nujiang  prefecture.  About  91%  of  the 
population is rural with a poverty incidence of more than 60% and an average net income per capita of CNY1,128 in 
2002. The Project  considered these counties within BOA as part of its due diligence of the potential adverse impacts 
on local ethnic populations.  
 
The  Project  will  benefit  poor  people  in  the  project  area  through  direct  benefits  from  employment  during  the 
construction and operation of the railway. It is estimated that 96,800 person-years of work spread over 3.5 years will 
be needed to construct the railway, or about 27,670 person-years of work per year. Of these, 60% will be for unskilled 
laborers, of which 50% or more will be targeted to poor ethnic minority households. Priority will be given to women and 
people  from  resettlement-affected  households.  Employment  will  be  created  through  the  use  of  locally  produced 
materials for railway construction (e.g., cement). The Project will finance 251 kilometers (km) of construction access 
roads, which will be handed over to the local government at the end of the construction period. The construction of 
passenger stations, using architecture unique to the ethnic minority of the area, will cater to the information needs of 
passengers and touris ts. There will be sufficient space in or around the stations for local area development. Kiosks or 
concession  stalls  will  be  incorporated  into  the  design  of  these  intermediate  stations.  Local  governments  will  be 
encouraged  to  convert  additional  space  around  the  railway  stations  for  commercial  businesses.  This  will  have 
immediate benefits for the local poor population. 
 
The Project will also provide efficient and low-cost transportation for passengers and goods, which will improve access 
to markets, and help the development of natural resources and industry in the area. Local government will prioritize a 
number of rural roads for upgrading to provide better access of economic opportunities that the railway will generate 
for remote communities. These improvements will help generate additional opportunities for the poor population in the 
BOA through indirect project benefits, which will increase in the long run.

The  participation  of  local  people  will  be  central  for  improving  their  opportunities  to  benefit  from  the  Project. Local 
groups  and  relevant  government  agencies  continue  to  be  involved  in  the  consultation  and  participation  process, 
especially during the implementation of the EIA, resettlement plan, and EMDP. Railway support offices exist in each 
project county, and will have copies of all relevant documents. During construction and operation, they will serve as 
key  coordinating  points  to  enhance  stakeholder  participation.    Relevant  line  agencies  will  also  help  support  the 
implementation of the EIA, resettlement plan, and EMDP. 

D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
During project preparation, analyses of sex-disaggregated data and discussions with representatives of the All-China 
Women’s  Federation  indicate  that  women  are  considered  vulnerable.  Data  collected  for  the  poverty  and  social 
assessment,  the  EMDP,  and  the  resettlement  plan  indicate  the  following:  (i) women  constitute  46%  of  the  total 
population in the project area; (ii) women primarily engage in agricultural activities; (iii) the female labor participation 
rate is high—approximately 48%; and (iv)  male members from poor households tend to travel further for migrant labor 
opportunities  than  nonpoor  males,  leaving  behind  a  high  percentage  of  households  headed  by  women.  A 
representative from Lijiang Women’s Federation supported the Project for the additional opportunities it would bring to 
women.  For  instance,  the  construction  of  the  railway  would  create  opportunities  for  local  area  development  by 
(i) facilitating  flow  of  materials  and  information  into  the  area,  and  (ii) accelerating  development  of  local  industry—
primarily agricultural and tourism.  
 
Poverty  and  social  enhancement  measures  have  been  built  into  the  project  design,  and  special  mitigation  (or 
protection)  actions  have  been  included  into  the  resettlement  plan  and  the  EMDP.  For  example,  members  of  the 
community will collectively decide where schools will be relocated. Women, especially female heads of household, will 
be consulted as schools provide an informal source of daycare for  their children. Widows will be eligible for special 
assistance, if necessary, during land acquisition and resettlement. Women will be given priority for project-generated 
employment  during  construction  and  operation  of  the  railway,  including  afforestation  activities.  The  rise  in  female 
participation in the labor force and tourism market will increase women’s net income, thus improving overall family 
welfare,  and  increasing  the  status  of  women.  There  is  potential  for  adverse  impacts  on  the  Mosuo  minorities —a 
matriarchal society located in the BOA (Lugu lake in Ninglang) caused by excessive tourism development. However, 
the local government and the Mosuo communities are already taking action to preserve their culture and tradition. This 
sensitive  situation  will  be  monitored  during  project  construction  to  ensure  actions  are  effective;  otherwise,  further 
measures would be required before the Project is completed.
